en.value: Have you seen the news?
Talking about different types of media, reacting to the news - past tense revision
Types of media

In this unit you'll learn some useful words and phrases for talking about different types of media. We can share information with a large number of people via the media. For example, you can read, watch or listen to the news...
... on television
... on the radio
... on the internet
... in the newspaper
... on social media
... on a blog
Here's a tip!
in the news
My hometown has been in the news recently.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Our company has been [k]in the news[/k] a lot lately.
the news
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
When we say "in the news", this refers widely to the news in all sorts of media. However, you might hear people say "on the news" when they are talking about something on a particular news programme.
I saw your school on the news last night!
Yes! It's been in the news a lot recently.
in the newspaper
Did you read her new article in yesterday's newspaper?
Did you read her article [k]i[/k]n the [k]n[/k][k]e[/k][k]w[/k][k]s[/k]paper?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
on television
Millions watched the football live on television last night.
In spoken language, we often say "on TV" instead of "on television". It is shorter and more natural.
There's a new series on TV and it's really good!
Did you watch that documentary about the global warming on TV last night?
We were watching the news [k]on TV[/k] last night.
on the radio
We normally listen to the news on the radio.
on the internet
We always get the most up-to-date news on the internet.
Click on the sentence with the same meaning as the audio.
We normally listen to the news on the radio.
We were watching the news on TV last night.
We always get the most up-to-date news on the internet.
Match the two parts of the sentences, which contain different past tenses.
Did you watch the documentary
Have you heard
We always get the most up-to-date news
on television last night?
the news yet?
on the internet.
on social media
I often discuss the latest news with my friends on social media.
When we talk about "social media" we usually mean websites where people can share information in the form of personal messages or comments.
Do you connect with people [k]on social[/k] [k]media[/k]?
in social
online
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
on a blog
The news has appeared on a live blog.
You can sometimes say "in a blog" and sometimes "on a blog". Both variants are correct.
I read it in a blog.
She posted this picture on her blog.
Have you read her latest [k]blog post[/k] yet?
post blog
Click on three different types of media.
Did you read her article in the [h]newspaper[/h]?
We normally listen to the [h]radio[/h].
We watched a film on [h]TV[/h] last night.
Do you remember the present perfect tense? We can use it to announce some news or to talk about something that has happened recently.
I have just heard it on the radio.
Have you watched it on TV recently?
Her resignation has been all over the news!
We can use the present perfect tense to announce some news.
True or false?
Have you heard? Peter [k]has[/k] just [k]got[/k] a new job!
have
get
[k]Have[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]read[/k] [k]her[/k] [k]latest[/k] [k]blog[/k] [k]post?[/k]
Select the words in the correct order.
She [k]hasn't[/k] [k]announced[/k] her resignation yet.
haven't
announce
Do you remember? We often use the present perfect tense with the following adverbs: just, recently, already, yet, ever, never.
We were
Writing a blog has
Yesterday we didn't
watching the news on TV last night.
become very popular recently.
watch the evening news but we listened to it on the radio.
Click on the sentence with the present perfect tense.
last night [h]recently[/h] yesterday last year [h]just[/h] [h]already[/h] [h]yet[/h]
Have you heard the news yet?
Did you read her article in yesterday's newspaper?
Click on the present perfect forms in these sentences.
Mark and Lucy [h]have[/h] [h]announced[/h] their engagement!
We [h]haven't[/h] [h]posted[/h] our pictures on the blog yet.
This sentence contains the present perfect tense.
We were watching the news on TV last night.
"We were watching" is the Past Continous tense.
To announce the news or to talk about something that has happened recently, we use...
Present perfect
Past simple
Past continuous
[k]Have you heard[/k] the news yet?
Use the audio to complete the sentence.
Our company has been [k]in the news[/k] a lot lately.
[k]We[/k] [k]often[/k] [k]discuss[/k] [k]the news[/k] [k]on[/k] [k]social[/k] [k]media![/k]
[k]Millions[/k] [k]were[/k] [k]watching[/k] [k]the football[/k] [k]on television[/k] [k]last night.[/k]
Yesterday we listened to the news [k]on the radio[/k].
I read the news about their divorce [k]on social media[/k].
I've already [k]heard[/k] the news.
Complete the sentence with the correct form of the verb "to hear".
Our company [k]has[/k] been [k]in[/k] the news a lot lately.
We [k]were[/k] watching the documentary [k]on[/k] TV last night.
We always [k]get[/k] the most up-to-date news [k]on the[/k] internet.
Her new article was [k]published[/k] in yesterday's [k]newspaper[/k].
Do you watch the news [k]o[/k][k]n[/k] TV or listen to it [k]o[/k][k]n[/k] [k]t[/k][k]h[/k][k]e[/k] radio?
Reacting to good and bad news
There are many ways to react to different kinds of news. We're going to look at some useful phrases in this unit.
That's great / amazing news!
I can't believe it!
I'm really pleased / sorry to hear that!
That's awful!
Oh my goodness!
This is ridiculous!
That's great news!
When something bad or unpleasant has happened, you can say...
That's terrible!
That's awful!
Oh dear!
You might say this when you hear some bad news.
That's awful!
I can't believe it!
I'm really pleased to hear that!
If you want to show sympathy for someone you can say...
I'm really sorry to hear that.
You say this when you receive good news.
I'm really pleased to hear that!
When you are surprised you might say...
Wow!
Really?
Oh my goodness!
This is ridiculous!
You might say this to show surprise or disagreement.
This is ridiculous!
When you really like something you can say...
That's amazing!
That's brilliant!
How wonderful!
How wonderful!
Really?
Oh my goodness!
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Choose the phrase with the similar meaning to "I'm really sorry to hear that!"
That's awful!
That's amazing!
Select the three positive words you might use when you hear good news...
[h]amazing[/h] terrible [h]wonderful[/h] awful [h]great[/h]
[k]I'm[/k] [k]really[/k] [k]pleased[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]hear[/k] [k]that![/k]
I can't [k]b[/k][k]e[/k]l[k]i[/k][k]e[/k][k]v[/k]e it!
[k]That[/k] [k]is[/k] [k]amazing[/k][k]![/k]
This is [k]r[/k][k]i[/k][k]d[/k][k]i[/k][k]c[/k][k]u[/k]l[k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]s[/k]!
Oh my [k]goodness[/k]! They are getting married!
Use the audio to complete the sentence.
Really? This is [k]ridiculous[/k]! You can't do that!
[k]Wow![/k] That's [k]amazing![/k] I absolutely love it!
Sorry!
awful!
That's [k]great|wonderful|amazing[/k] news.
Write an answer to: Harry has just got a new job!
That's [k]g[/k][k]r[/k][k]e[/k][k]a[/k][k]t[/k] news!
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Have you [k]heard[/k] the news yet? Mark and Kelly are getting married!
Oh I can't believe it! That's [k]amazing[/k]! At last! They've known each other for so long.
They've just announced their engagement in the local newspaper.
I'm really [k]pleased[/k] to hear that. Where are they getting married?
Well, [k]they've[/k] decided to have the ceremony in Bali.
Oh my goodness, that's [k]ridiculous[/k]! Can't they have it at home like everyone else?
I know, but it seems like everybody wants to be trendy these days and post exotic pictures on their blogs and on [k]social media[/k].
[k]Exactly[/k]!
Martin
Harriet
Oh, I can't believe it! That's amazing!
Harriet sounds surprised and excited.
Mark and Kelly have announced their engagement...
in the newspaper.
on the radio.
on television.
Harriet is ... to hear the news.
happy
upset
sorry
[k]Oh[/k] [k]my[/k] [k]goodness,[/k] [k]that's[/k] [k]great[/k] [k]news![/k]
Harriet thinks that having the wedding ceremony in Bali is...
ridiculous.
amazing.
awful.
Oh, I [k]can't believe it[/k]! That's amazing! At last! They've known each other for so long.
